title: Arthur Pole Penton
text:
Major-General Arthur Pole Penton (6 October 185428 August 1920) was a British officer in the <a href="Royal%20Artillery">Royal Artillery</a>, and Commandant of the New Zealand Defence Forces from 1897 to 1901.
Military career.
Penton was commissioned a <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in the Royal Artillery on 9 January 1873. He served in the <a href="Second%20Anglo-Afghan%20War">Second Anglo-Afghan War</a> in 1878 and was <a href="mentioned%20in%20dispatches">mentioned in dispatches</a>. Promotion to <a href="Captain%20%28BARM%29">captain</a> came on 7 July 1882, and to <a href="Major%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">major</a> on 1 October 1889. He was Commandant of the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Defence%20Force">New Zealand Defence Force</a>s between 1896 and 1901, during which he received the substantive promotion to <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant-colonel</a> on 15 December 1898.
In 1902 he was in charge of the Militia and Volunteer Artillery in the North-Eastern district, in command of the depôt at <a href="Scarborough%2C%20North%20Yorkshire">Scarborough, North Yorkshire</a>. For services in connection with the colonial military contingents visiting the United Kingdom for the 1902 <a href="Coronation%20of%20King%20Edward%20VII%20and%20Queen%20Alexandra">Coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra</a>, he was awarded the <a href="King%20Edward%20VII%20Coronation%20Medal">Coronation Medal</a> in silver. He was promoted to <a href="Colonel%20%28British%20Army%29">colonel</a> on 15 December 1902.
He was also Member of the <a href="Executive%20Council%20of%20Malta">Executive Council of Malta</a> from 1909 until his death in 1920.
He was made CVO in 1909, CB in 1910, and CMG in <a href="1917%20New%20Year%20Honours">1917</a>.
Family.
His daughter Beryl Katherine married <a href="Sir%20Robert%20Lock">Sir Robert Lock</a>.
